contentrichtext.text: {{about||the baseball player|Ed Boland|the American actor|Eddie Boland}} {{Infobox Congressman | name=Edward Boland | image name=Edward Boland (1961).jpg | caption =1961 photo of Boland. | state=[[Massachusetts]] | district=[[Massachusetts's 2nd congressional district|2nd]] | term=January 3, 1953 – January 3, 1989 | preceded=[[Foster Furcolo]] | succeeded=[[Richard Neal]] | birth_name=Edward Patrick Boland | birth_date={{birth date|1911|10|1|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Springfield, Massachusetts]] | death_date={{death date and age|2001|11|4|1911|10|1|mf=y}} | death_place=Springfield, Massachusetts | spouse= | profession= | religion= | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |}} '''Edward Patrick Boland''' (October 1, 1911 – November 4, 2001) was a [[politician]] from the [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Massachusetts]]. A [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], he was a representative from [[Massachusetts's 2nd congressional district]]. Boland's father was an [[Irish people|Irish]] immigrant railroad worker.<ref>{{cite news|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|title=Rep. Edward Boland, 90; Opposed Aid to Contras|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/06/local/me-854|accessdate=December 16, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 6, 2001}}</ref> Boland was born in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] and graduated from [[Springfield Central High School]] in 1928. He attended [[Bay Path College|Bay Path Institute]] and [[Boston College Law School]]. He was a member of the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] from 1939 to 1940 and was the [[Hampden County, Massachusetts|Hampden County]] [[Recorder of deeds|register of deeds]] from 1941 to 1952. He also served in the [[United States Army]] during [[World War II]].<ref name="congress bio">{{cite web|title=BOLAND, Edward Patrick, (1911 - 2001)|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000600|work=Biographical Directory of the United States Congress|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref> [[File:Edward Boland (1983).jpg|thumb|left|1983 autographed photo of Boland.]] Boland was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]] as a [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democrat]] in 1952.<ref name="congress bio"/> Boland's most famous work as a Congressman was the 1982 [[Boland Amendment]], which blocked further funding of the [[Contra (guerrillas)|Contras]] in [[Nicaragua]] after the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] had supervised acts of sabotage without notifying [[Congress of the United States|Congress]].<ref name="contras">{{cite web|title=The Counterrevolutionaries (The Contras)|url=http://www.brown.edu/Research/Understanding_the_Iran_Contra_Affair/n-contrasus.php|work=Understanding the Iran-Contra Affairs|publisher=Brown University|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref> Boland lived in a Washington apartment with [[Tip O'Neill]] (whose wife remained in Massachusetts) until 1977 and he married at the age of 62, fathering four children. Boland retired from the House in 1989. Boland died in 2001 at the age of 90 from natural causes.<ref name="Globe obit">{{cite news|last=Feeney|first=Mark|title=Longtime congressman Edward Boland dies|url=http://www.boston.com/dailyglobe2/310/metro/Longtime_congressman_Edward_Boland_dies+.shtml|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=November 6, 2001|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20011121071744/http://www.boston.com/dailyglobe2/310/metro/Longtime_congressman_Edward_Boland_dies+.shtml|archivedate=November 21, 2001}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{CongBio|B000600}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Massachusetts | district=2 | before=[[Foster Furcolo]] | after=[[Richard Neal]] | years= January 3, 1953 – January 3, 1989}} {{s-end}} {{House Intel Chairmen}} {{USRepMA}} {{Authority control|VIAF=39303455}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Boland, Edward P. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American politician | DATE OF BIRTH = October 1, 1911 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] | DATE OF DEATH = November 4, 2001 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Springfield, Massachusetts]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boland, Edward P.}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Massachusetts]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Boston College Law School alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Massachusetts House of Representatives]] [[Category:People from Springfield, Massachusetts]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]]
